We'll dig deeper into the controversy over Centra. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Stocks sold off late in the day. The Dow lost 345 today. The S&P 500 fell 42. The NASDAQ gave back 98. We're learning new details tonight about some of the ways big tech is keeping track of you and your family. There's growing controversy over a Facebook tool that makes it all possible without your knowledge. But the head of the company insists he's not familiar with it. Here is Edward Lawrence of Fox Business. EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT (voice over): Facebook executive searching for answers in a sea of accusations about tracking and company behavior. Missouri Senator Josh Hawley shot Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, confronting him with whistleblower information that Facebook routinely tracks people across the Internet with a program called Centra, as well as works with other text giants on what and who to censor. Today, Facebook confirming to Fox Business, Centra exists, but adding, it's only used to aid complex investigations to inauthentic behavior. Zuckerberg dodged the questions yesterday.

utterances.speaker: SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO)
utterances.sentences: What is the Facebook internal tool called Centra? if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb19', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb19', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: MARK ZUCKERBERG, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, FACEBOOK
utterances.sentences: Senator, I'm not aware of any tool with that name.

utterances.speaker: HAWLEY
utterances.sentences: There's a demonstrative now over my shoulder, Centra is a tool that Facebook uses to track its users not just on Facebook, but across the entire Internet.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE
utterances.sentences: Senator Hawley also pressing Facebook about coordinated censorship. Hawley, says the whistleblower outlined for him the tool called tasks that allows communication between Facebook, Twitter, and Google about what topics, hashtags, and people to censor. Facebook says it's for investigations. Adding, "We are proud of the work we do together on security issues and fighting child exploitation -- and are public about that." Representative Steve Scalise, adding, social media companies are on a slippery slope.

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA)
utterances.sentences: They're not just letting content out there, by the way. The idea that they should have those Section 30 -- 230 protections against being sued, it shouldn't apply if you're starting to pick and choose whose views you're going to put out there in the public square. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Edward, thanks. Up next, we talked to governors from both parties with differing ideas on how to keep their residents safe from coronavirus.

utterances.speaker: GOV. LAURA KELLY (D-KS)
utterances.sentences: The last component in our new all of the above strategy is an executive order that I'm issuing today, implementing a new statewide face-covering protocol.

utterances.speaker: GOV. TATE REEVES (R-MS)
utterances.sentences: We're not going to participate in a nationwide lockdown. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: GOV. TONY EVERS (D-WI)
utterances.sentences: The best way to get through this is to -- is to be together by from afar.

utterances.speaker: GOV. MIKE DEWINE (R-OH)
utterances.sentences: I don't intend to send agents out to knock on people's doors, go into their backyard, go down to their rec room.

utterances.speaker: GOV. GAVIN NEWSOM (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: I made a bad mistake. I need to preach and practice. Not just preach and not practice.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Governors across the nation with different approaches to curbing the spread of the coronavirus, and it is spreading throughout the country. As we told you at the top of the program, surging cases forcing many state and local governments to take some major steps toward containment. The last 24-hour reporting period showed almost 162,000 new infections for a total of 11-1/3 million cases. We are going to talk tonight about regulations, restrictions, other possible ways to deal with the situation we are seeing in the country. Joining us, governors from both parties. Republican Tate Reeves of Mississippi will be with us shortly. First up, we'll talk to Kansas Democratic Governor Laura Kelly. Governor Kelly, thanks for being here. I know you're dealing with surges in your state as we're seeing across the country. What are you doing now to deal with that?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.sentences: Well, we are experiencing a huge surge just like many other states. But just today, in response to that, we introduced a sort of multi-pronged approach to this. I did issue another executive order mandating face- covering protocols. But we did it with a little bit of a twist. I had done that once before in July. This time around, we've set the protocols, we've set the standard for across Kansas. But we are giving those counties that previously opted out of the mandate and there were about 70 of 105 counties here in Kansas that did opt-out. We're going to give them a one week to put together their own ordinance, instead of opting into our ordinance. So that they can have a little control, have a little ownership, and make it flexible enough to allow them to do what they think will work in their county. Then, in addition to that --

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Governor, do you see a lot of pushback?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.sentences: No. Actually, I'm not. You know, I had conversations with Republican leadership yesterday and today. I've had conversations with -- my offices had conversations with the Kansas Chamber of Commerce and other business entities. And I think we actually have a lot of support for taking this approach because we are giving some flexibility and autonomy to our local elected officials to put in place what worked for them. Do they need to have a face-covering protocol in place? Absolutely. But we think, and we've seen what we've learned over the last nine months is that one size does not fit all. And so, we want them to develop something that will work for them. But in addition to that, we're going to support them through a very robust public service announcement program that's being put together by our Kansas Hospital Association, the Kansas Chamber of Commerce, the Kansas Farm Bureau, and other groups. That will begin airing next week, just before Thanksgiving. That will encourage people, give them the education they need to understand the importance of the face coverings. So, we're going to do that. And then, we've formed a partnership with our Kansas leadership center, which trains local leaders all across the state on routine basis. They're going to engage about 2,000 of their alums. And we're going to create a virus busting task force that will work all across the state in our local communities, with folks, their neighbors, their friends, to encourage them to follow the face mask protocols, but also to do all of the other things that will mitigate the spread of this virus.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.sentences: And allow us to keep our business open, allow us to keep our schools open, and decrease the pressure on our hospitals.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Right. And what I'm not hearing from you is lockdown, because there are a lot of people across the country that are fearful of that. They saw what happened March to May, Kansas dropped, like the nation, some 37 percent as far as businesses and tax revenues coming into your state. You've had in Wichita, I guess, suicides up more than 70 percent, and we're seeing some of that from some of this lockdown fear. But I'm not hearing that in what you're saying as far as how you're going to address it, and you're also waiting, obviously, for a vaccine.

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.sentences: Yes, we are not going that route. We have learned a lot over the nine months of this pandemic, and we took some pretty drastic action at the beginning because we didn't know anything else to do. But now we do know that there are other ways to mitigate the spread of this virus, and we've worked very closely with our business communities from way back at the beginning of this time, we've worked with our school districts, and we're working with just the general public and our healthcare professionals and all of those to put in place things that we know will mitigate the spread of the virus and buy us the time until a vaccine is developed and distributed widely.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Governor, we appreciate your time. Good luck fighting this thing. Every governor is dealing with it, from Topeka, Kansas. Thank you. Let's bring in Mississippi Republican Governor Tate Reeves. Governor Reeves, thanks for being here. You just heard Governor Kelly from Kansas. Your thoughts, what are you doing?

utterances.speaker: GOV. TATE REEVES, (R-MS)
utterances.sentences: Bret, thanks for having me on today. And one of the things that I was glad to hear my colleague say is that one size does not fit all. It's why those that are clamoring for a national strategy do not realize what those of us as governors that are in the trenches, that are working every single day. What's best for Kansas today is not necessarily what's best for Mississippi. And in fact, I have got 82 counties in my great state, and what's best in the northeast part of our state where numbers are in a certain spot versus what's best for the Mississippi gulf coast are different. And that's why we are taking a county by county approach. We began this dating all the way back to late June, early July. And we have an objective criteria in place in which if any county has more than 200 cases over a two-week period, or more than 500 cases per 100,000 residents, then we put additional measures in place, more strict measures in place, which may or may not include a mask mandate. It certainly includes having smaller-sized gatherings and other things such as that. And so, again, it's very important that governors have autonomy to do what's best for their constituents. And when you talk about the notion of lockdowns, one of the reasons people are so concerned about that right now is because some of the leading experts that are advising the Biden administration are certainly suggesting that. And so we're going to push back against that as well. I'm glad to hear that there are Republican and Democrat governors across the country that agree that that's not the right approach to take.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Governor, you're seeing your hospitalization rates go up. You have a test positive rate in Mississippi, according to Johns Hopkins, at 18.8 percent. That's a concerning number, but you're saying you are handling it different in different parts of the state.

utterances.speaker: REEVES
utterances.sentences: Yes, well, the reality is that we have seen a slight uptick in cases. We are nowhere near where we were back during the summer months. If you'll recall, many of the southeastern conference states, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia had a very, very challenging summer. At that time, we actually had 1,250 hospitalizations at our peak, and that was on July 26th. Today we have approximately 850. So we're somewhere in the neighborhood of 65 to 70 percent of total hospitalizations at our peak. We're very pleased that there are a number of good things that are coming out that are going to help us deal with this virus. The antibody opportunities that exist in terms of the therapeutics is a huge move in the right direction for us. I was talking with a state health officers about that earlier today. It's going to allow us to treat as many as 700 patients in the near term. In addition to that, the vaccine is just around the corner. And so what we all need to be talking about is how do we bridge the gap from where we find ourselves today where we are seeing rises cases in our state and every other state around the nation, how do we bridge that gap from today to when we have more and more distribution of the two vaccines that have literally in the last couple weeks been discussed?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: You mentioned SEC football. That's a big deal down there. You had the Texas A&M-Ole Miss game canceled. Do you think SEC is going to be able to finish this season?

utterances.speaker: REEVES
utterances.sentences: We'll, there's not doubt that we've had some challenges over the last several weeks. There's been a large number of games that have been canceled. And the reason for that is because we're seeing significant numbers increase in community transmission. As total numbers increase across our states, then obviously a larger number of those associated with the program, football players, et cetera, are testing positive as well, which is making challenges. So my plea to everyone in the southeastern conference and everyone who cares about college football around the country or cares about sports in general is the best way we can ensure that they go forward is by doing our part. Let's do the little things that make a difference. Let's wear a mask. Let's stay in small groups even over Thanksgiving. Let's be personally responsible. We don't need the government to tell us what to do. We as individuals just need to recognize that we can do some little things to make a big difference.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Across party lines, Governor Reeves, we appreciate your time. Governor Kelly earlier from Kansas. Thank you both for being on, dealing with this coronavirus pandemic. Up next, the State Department says China wants to replace the U.S. as the most powerful nation on earth. We will look at how they might try to do that and what the U.S. is doing about it.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: We are getting fresh information about just how seriously the U.S. government is taking the growing threat from China. A new report says the Beijing leadership is intent on displacing the U.S. as the world's most powerful nation. Correspondent Benjamin Hall looks at the implications of that tonight from London.

utterances.speaker: BENJAMIN HALL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: A new generation of Chinese fighter pilots landing on a new generation of Chinese carriers, wargames simulating the naval invasion of Taiwan, further arrests of opposition lawmakers in Hong Kong, and high in the Himalayas, reports that China used a secret microwave weapon to incapacitate Indian soldiers. China has also now signed a major trade deal with 14 other Asian-Pacific countries, the first that unites China, Japan, South Korea, and Australia. China has been flexing its military and economic muscles, and the State Department is paying close attention, issuing a warning to the incoming administration, saying "The CCP aims not merely at preeminence within the established world order, but to fundamentally revise world order, placing the People's Republic of China at the center and serving Beijing's authoritarian goals and hegemonic ambitions." President Trump has repeatedly criticized Democrats for failing to address China's behavior, and there remains little clarity on President-elect Biden's plans for the U.S./China relationship.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.sentences: We need to be aligned with the other democracies, another 25 percent or more, so that we can set the rules of the road instead of having China and others dictate outcomes because they are the only game in town.

utterances.speaker: HALL
utterances.sentences: China has congratulated President-elect Biden, but they remain cautious of President Trump. State media reporting that Beijing is preparing for what they say could be a, quote, final act of madness from President Trump to sabotage Biden's presidency.

utterances.speaker: HALL
utterances.sentences: There is a growing and bipartisan belief that the U.S. needs a more aggressive approach towards China. Whether President-elect Biden shares that approach remains to be seen. Bret?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Benjamin, thank you. Up next, the panel on the vote recount, the Georgia runoffs, the latest with the coronavirus, all of that. First beyond our borders tonight. German police unleash watercannons and pepper spray in an effort to scatter thousands of protestors angry about a new legal framework for enforcing coronavirus restrictions. The legislation was passed by parliament today in Germany today. Police detained 190 people, nine officers were injured. The head of the U.N. atomic watchdog agency confirms reports Iran has begun operating centrifuges installed at an underground site. But the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency says the centrifuges were moved from another facility, so the country's overall uranium enriching capabilities have not increased. Today the U.S. imposed broad sanctions targeting Iran and blacklisted a foundation controlled by the country's Supreme Leader. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Israel today along with Bahrain's foreign minister, which was a first official visit from the kingdom to Israel. For his part Pompeo's visit may include a tour of a West Bank winery, which would be the first time a top American diplomat has visited an Israeli settlement. Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: MARK GODSEY, MICHIGAN BOWLING ALLEY OWNER
utterances.sentences: In my whole life I never thought my government would tell me I have to close. I can go through recessions and I can do all that. It's my fault if I don't make it. It's not my fault this time, and I have no choice. And I'm only a mile from the Indiana border, and they're open. And so it makes it pretty hard to swallow.

utterances.speaker: GOV. GRETCHEN WHITMER, (D-MI)
utterances.sentences: I have incredible empathy for what they're struggling with, and yet we have to follow the epidemiology, the public health experts, and make decisions that combat the spread before our hospitals get overwhelmed and before we hit 1,000 deaths a week in Michigan, because that's what the modeling is telling us where we're headed right now.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Small business owners really trying to figure out how to keep going in this environment as different state and local governments decide to do different things with the coronavirus. This as we have just passed, according to Johns Hopkins University, 250,000 deaths in the U.S., the cases now 11,485,000. That is eighth in the world per capita when it comes to deaths of the major countries in the world. That's where we are at this moment a week before Thanksgiving. Let's bring in our panel, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," A.B. Stoddard, associate editor at Real Clear Politics, and Byron York, chief political correspondent for the "Washington Examiner." Charlie, you heard Governors Kelly and Reeves from Kansas and Mississippi trying to thread the needle here to not hurt small businesses, but also deal with this surge. And it's a real challenge. CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "WASHINGTON TIMES": It sure is a real challenge, and I think that in a lot of ways we may be understating just how much this crisis will define politics probably for the next 15 years in this country. And I think that -- quite frankly I think it stands to hurt politicians who are trying to do these lockdowns and do these mandates, because I think that a lot of people feel like we've tried those things and, obviously, the pandemic continues. It continues to spread. And at the end of the day, it's going to be things like the therapeutics, the vaccines, and of course personal responsibility across the board that is going to be what -- Americans are funny. They can have a lot of funny opinions about a lot of different things. But one thing that they really do care about, they like their freedom. And I think that these kinds of mandates, especially when the people that are pushing them are violating their own mandates, I think that sort of thing tends to turn a political environment toxic.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: A.B., the poster boy for that, it appears, this week is the California Governor Gavin Newsom, who was shot, photographed at this dinner at the French Laundry in Napa with a group of people, without a mask, in an area closed down just after giving this big speech about how Thanksgiving had to be locked down and people need to be wearing masks at all times, even with family members, under 10 people. Here is his apology. Take a listen.

utterances.speaker: GOV. GAVIN NEWSOM, (D-CA)
utterances.sentences: As soon as I sat down at the larger table, I realized it was a little larger group than I had anticipated. And I made a bad mistake. You can quibble about the guidelines, et cetera, et cetera, but the spirit of what I'm preaching all the time was contradicted, and I got to own that. And so I want to apologize to you, because I need to preach and practice, not just preach and not practice.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: So that's happening to politicians all over the country, too. But the bottom line is everybody has to figure out a way to deal with this.

utterances.speaker: A.B. STODDARD, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, REAL CLEAR POLITICS
utterances.sentences: Yes, I wonder what the nurses and doctors who have been through this all year in California and have had just been in a state of complete anguish and trauma, if they're still alive and uninfected, think of the governor doing that and then trying to backtrack in that kind of a speech. The problem is there was never going to be a safe scenario in an indoor party at the French Laundry, and even if it wasn't on video, certainly his fancy friends were going to brag that they were at dinner with him at the French Laundry. So the thing is ludicrous. Everyone has to lead by example, and they have to take responsibility for the fact that our healthcare system is at the breaking point. And we know from the models and the experts, because they have studied what has happened Memorial Day, July Fourth, Sturgis rally, on and on, what happens when a Trump rally comes to a county -- all these things create more infection. And we know what will happen to our hospitals at Christmastime if everyone plans to gather, at Thanksgiving. And what the governor of California did is completely hypocritical, and he is not living up to the sacrifice he is asking people to make so that we can have space in the ICU wards of these hospitals for people who are not taking responsibility and are spreading the disease.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Byron, obviously Operation Warp Speed has been very successful to get us as a country to this point with not only the vaccines and the logistics that is yet to come, but also the therapeutics that are coming today, fast test at home approved by Pfizer. Those are all positive things, but they don't come right away. BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": No, it's going to take a while. And there will be a big political fight over the distribution of those that will straddle the end of the Trump administration and the beginning of the Biden administration. I think the real main fact to remember about vaccines is that President Trump promised a vaccine in record time, and there will be vaccines, plural, in record time. But I thought it was really interesting what Governor Kelly and Governor Reeves were telling you. Clearly, they don't believe in any sort of national one size fits all policy. They don't believe even in statewide one size fits all policies. They are making policies county by county in their states, depending on conditions, and there was absolutely zero taste among either one, Republican and Democrat, for lockdowns. They felt like they learned a lot during the lockdown period months ago, and they don't want to do that again even when the virus is a big threat.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Charlie, do you think families, a lot of them are saying if you are number 11, you're out on the porch, 10 or under on the inside? What do you think families around the country are dealing with when it comes to these restrictions?

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.sentences: I really don't think that's the case. I think people are going to continue to operate in a responsible way. They are going to wear masks if they can't social distance. They're going to wash their hands. They're going to keep their distance. But I don't think that people are going to be cutting off people from Thanksgiving. I know my family certainly won't be cutting off people from the Thanksgiving table because of this.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: If I have a TV outside, I'm OK. I can sit on the porch. Panel, thank you so much. When we come back, reunited, and you know the rest.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.sentences: Finally tonight, back together again. Old work pals, Marion Darbyshire and Winnie Shaw were inseparable friends as young apprentices at a British sewing factory. The pair eventually lost contact with Winnie left that factory. And after 73 years the two were reunited after bumping into each other at the Manchester, England, care home where they both live. How about that? Elsewhere in England, Harry Wilsden and his wife Doreen were reunited in a care home in Darlington after nearly two months apart. The pair were separated after Harry contracted the coronavirus. Doreen said she could hardly believe her eyes when she saw her husband and that's a good thing. Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now. utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: Hello, Greg. Good evening (AUDIO GAP) Bret Baier. Development of a coronavirus vaccine as additional state and local governments take drastic steps to try to control the spread including the suspension of classroom education in the nation's largest public school district. But there is more promising (AUDIO GAP) agency authorization for its vaccine from the Food and Drug Administration within days. The FDA has also just approved a rapid test that can be performed at home. Stores in some areas are reporting massive runs on essential items with retailers such as Walmart and grocers, Kroger and Publix saying they're having trouble keeping many products on their shelves. This has many people prepare for Thanksgiving, including in Michigan, or new rules are in effect tonight. Meaning, no in-person school or indoor activities such as dining and movie theaters. Correspondent Garrett Tenney begins our coverage tonight from Lansing, Michigan. Good evening, Garrett.

utterances.speaker: GARRETT TENNEY, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Bret, good evening to you. As these new restrictions go into effect, today the U.S. set another record high with more than 76,000 people hospitalized with COVID-19. But also said -- also today, some potentially game changing developments.

utterances.speaker: TENNEY (Voice over)
utterances.utterance: A vaccine could be just around the corner. Today, Pfizer announcing its vaccine proved to be 95 percent effective in preventing infections and didn't cause any serious side effects. The company's CEO said they plan to file an emergency use request with the FDA on Friday, opening the door for it to become the first COVID-19 vaccine to hit the market.

utterances.speaker: ALEX AZAR, U.S. SECRETARY, HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
utterances.utterance: By the end of December, we expect to have about 40 million doses of these two vaccines available for distribution.

utterances.speaker: TENNEY
utterances.utterance: At home testing took another big step forward today as well as the FDA approved the first rapid test that can be completed at home. According to the company Lucira, the test can provide results within half an hour and will cost $50.00 or less. Those developments are particularly encouraging given the surge of new cases flooding the country and new restrictions going into effect.

utterances.speaker: BILL DE BLASIO (D), MAYOR OF NEW YORK
utterances.utterance: We're going to fight this back. This is a setback, but it's a setback we will overcome.

utterances.speaker: TENNEY
utterances.utterance: Today, New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio announced schools will be shutting down indefinitely starting tomorrow. And new restrictions in other cities and states will impact Thanksgiving celebrations. In Oregon, no more than six people from two households are allowed to gather. In Chicago and Philadelphia, officials want everyone to have a Thanksgiving alone. And for those who decide to get together anyways, New Jersey State guidelines ask folks to encourage their guests not to sing or shout. While in Pennsylvania, you're required to wear a mask inside your own home if you have anyone over. The CDC itself recommends wearing a mask the entire time avoiding singing and bringing your own utensils, but elected officials continue to have trouble following those recommendations themselves. California Governor Gavin Newsom is under fire after new pictures surfaced of a birthday party he and his wife attended earlier this month, along with officials from the California Medical Association. Showing the dinner was not outside as he's claimed, no one's wearing a mask and one witness said the group was so loud, the restaurant sliding doors had to be closed.

utterances.speaker: TENNEY (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Hospitals across the country are overwhelmed. Many close to the breaking point but this virus shows no signs of letting up. And with folks gathering for the holidays, doctors are concerned about a potential flood of new cases over the next month, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Garrett Tenney in Lansing, Michigan. Garrett, thanks. Coming up shortly, we talked to two governors, one Democrat, one Republican about their very different strategies to deal with the coronavirus surge. Now, to the election aftermath, President Trump's team wants a vote recount in parts of Wisconsin. Additional uncounted ballots have turned up in several counties in Georgia as the hand recount there is coming to an end. President Trump also dealing with blowback from his firing of the country's top cybersecurity official when it comes to the election over comments contradicting the president's claims of widespread voter fraud. Chief White House correspondent John Roberts has details tonight. JOHN ROBERTS, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT (Voice over): The Trump campaign filing a petition today for a recount in two of Wisconsin's biggest counties, Milwaukee and Dane. In the initial tally, Milwaukee going 69 percent for Biden. Dane, which includes the capital of Madison going more than 75 percent in Biden's favor.

utterances.speaker: KAYLEIGH MCENANY, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: The President believes and so to do many others that if every legal vote is counted, he will remain president.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTS
utterances.utterance: In Georgia, where a recap is scheduled to wrap up at midnight, thousands of uncounted votes have been uncovered. In Floyd County, more than 2,600 uncounted ballots netted 800 votes for President Trump. In Fayette County, 2,755 ballots for a net Trump gain of 449 votes. 293 uncounted votes in Douglas County and 284 in Walton County netted the president another 148 votes. Still not enough to overturn the result, but plenty enough to reinforce the president's claims of voting irregularities.

utterances.speaker: REP. DOUG COLLINS (R-GA)
utterances.utterance: The Secretary of State's office has been telling everybody in Georgia, oh, everything was done proper. There's processes were done right, everything was right. And they've been pushing back and, you know, name calling and other things about people who didn't believe that this was why. But if we had not asked that, if I -- if the campaign had not asked for this recount, then you wouldn't have found those votes.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTS
utterances.utterance: President Trump has repeatedly criticized the voting machines Georgia and 29 other states used, Dominion Voting Systems. The president alleging in tweets that in jurisdictions using Dominion machines, votes for him were changed to votes for Biden. Dominion has repeatedly denied any impropriety in statement saying, Dominion Voting Systems categorically denies false assertions about vote switching and software issues with our voting systems. Supporters of the president have also raised questions about voting software called Smartmatic. A company with roots in Venezuela that has provided technology for several Venezuelan elections. Obama TSA chief Peter Neffenger, now a member of the Biden transition team is the chairman of Smartmatic's board. Both Smartmatic and Dominion have denied any connection to the other. And Trump supporters have leveled accusations that a CIA supercomputer called the Hammer and a software program called Scorecard were used to change votes. The former head of DHS's Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Agency Chris Krebs, he was fired last night by President Trump had dismissed those accusations as unfounded conspiracy theories, tweeting, I'm specifically referring to the Hammer and Scorecard nonsense. It's just that nonsense. This is not a real thing. Don't fall for it. The president fired Krebs for issuing a statement that the 2020 election was secure. The president tweeting, the recent statement by Chris Krebs on the security of the 2020 election was highly inaccurate, in that there were massive improprieties and fraud. Krebs firing was met with criticism from colleagues and others who believed he had done an excellent job.

utterances.speaker: SEN. CHUCK SCHUMER (D-NY)
utterances.utterance: To confirm that our elections were secure, reinforcing the number one rule of working for Donald Trump, you can never tell the truth. But no matter who he fires, or how many times he tweets, President Trump cannot change reality, he lost the presidential election.

utterances.speaker: ROBERTS (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Several Republican senators also had praise for Krebs for the job that he was doing. But his firing appears to be part of a larger narrative that President Trump is driving with his most devout supporters, that even if Joe Biden eventually does become president, it's not because President Trump lost the election, it's because it was taken from him, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: John Roberts live in the North Lawn. John, thanks. A state Board of Canvassers meetings scheduled for today and Michigan's largest county was canceled after canvassers in Wayne County unanimously certified election results showing Joe Biden defeating President Trump. That move came after two Republicans who had voted against certification, changed their votes last night. Their earlier refusal led the head of the local NAACP to call the Republican county canvassers a disgrace.

utterances.speaker: MONICA PALMER, WAYNE COUNTY BOARD OF CANVASSERS
utterances.utterance: I believe, that we do not have complete and accurate information on those polls.

utterances.speaker: REV. WENDELL ANTHONY, PRESIDENT, NAACP DETROIT BRANCH
utterances.utterance: Shame on you. Shame on you for leading to this level of corruption.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Those canvassers said they were pressured the vote count showed Biden defeating the president in Wayne County by more than a two to one margin. President-elect Joe Biden participating in a healthcare roundtable today in Wilmington, Delaware. Biden is also pushing for congressional action on student loan forgiveness and other costly programs. Correspondent Peter Doocy takes a look tonight from Wilmington.

utterances.speaker: PETER DOOCY, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT (Voice over)
utterances.utterance: If the president- elects plan to build back better, that'll cost $2 trillion for climate change.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, PRESIDENT-ELECT OF THE UNITED STATES
utterances.utterance: We're going to make historic investments. We'll seize the opportunity to meet this moment in history.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: On top of money for infrastructure.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: We have to invest over a trillion dollars in infrastructure, highways, roads, bridges that aren't unsafe.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: And healthcare.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: My program will cost about $750 billion over 10 years.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: Biden also believes some student loan debt should be forgiven by Congress before he's sworn in.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I've laid out in detail, for example, the legislation passed by the Democratic House calls for immediate $10,000 forgiveness of student loan. It should be done immediately.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: The transition team knows some progressives are upset that some incoming senior staff have in the past accepted donations from fossil fuel executives or have history lobbying for pharmaceutical companies. And an official tells Fox, the president-elect is determined to ensure that public servants serve all Americans not themselves or narrow special interests. Now, potential Cabinet nominees are being careful about what they say, including Susan Rice.

utterances.speaker: SUSAN RICE, FORMER UNITED STATES AMBASSADOR, UNITED NATIONS
utterances.utterance: If they think I can be helpful to them in any particular capacity, I'm very open to serving.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: The stalled formal transition could mean a stalled COVID-19 response in January.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: We've been unable to get access to the kinds of things we need to know about the depth of the stockpiles. We know there's not much at all.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: And COVID-19 concerns will mean a very slimmed down thanksgiving for the Bidens.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: I got a big family, you've probably heard a lot about. We do everything together. Well, you know, we're just not going to -- there's going to be three of us.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY
utterances.utterance: But the hardest thing for Biden to hear our stories from frontline workers like Mary, a nurse from Minnesota who says she's never been tested, which moves the president-elect to tears.

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: Mary --

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: I'm sorry, I'm so emotional. It's just --

utterances.speaker: BIDEN
utterances.utterance: You got me emotional.

utterances.speaker: DOOCY (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Biden phoned Nancy Pelosi again today, even though House Democrats have already approved the $3 trillion worth of COVID-19 relief that he wants done now. It is Senate Republicans who have not yet passed that measure, but since the election, Biden still has not spoken to Mitch McConnell, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Peter, thank you. Speaking of House Democrats, House Democrats have nominated Nancy Pelosi for another term as Speaker, but Pelosi faces some unique challenges this time around. Congressional correspondent Chad Pergram tells us what those are.

utterances.speaker: CHAD PERGRAM, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CONGRESSIONAL CORRESPONDENT (Voice over)
utterances.utterance: House Democrats are clinging to their majority that despite nearly losing control, Democrats are recycling the top three members of their leadership team. 80-year old James Clyburn and as whip 81-year old Steny Hoyer as majority leader and 80-year old Nancy Pelosi as Speaker. Pelosi is sticking to a promise two years ago to only serve a speaker through early 2023.

utterances.speaker: REP. NANCY PELOSI (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: I will abide by those limits that are there.

utterances.speaker: PERGRAM
utterances.utterance: But Pelosi cracked the door to staying on as Speaker.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: I didn't want to undermine any leverage I may have.

utterances.speaker: PERGRAM
utterances.utterance: No one challenged Pelosi for the top job despite some Democrats grousing privately about the need for new younger blood.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The speaker was elected with unbridled enthusiasm.

utterances.speaker: PERGRAM
utterances.utterance: Pelosi may have won in the caucus, but she needs a majority of the entire House when it formally selects the speaker in January. That's 218 votes out of 435. But the number of Democratic seats could be in the low 220s. And that would mean Pelosi would have little margin for error.

utterances.speaker: REP. KEVIN MCCARTHY (R-CA)
utterances.utterance: If 10 Democrats vote again against Nancy Pelosi, she will not be speaker. You see, the numbers are different.

utterances.speaker: PERGRAM
utterances.utterance: Pelosi lost 15 Democratic votes for speaker two years ago. She can't lose that many this time, including conservative Oregon Democrat Kurt Schrader. He voted two years ago for Ohio Democrat Marcia Fudge, Schrader is non-committal.

utterances.speaker: REP. KURT SCHRADER (D-OR)
utterances.utterance: Well, month and a half, two months. That's a long time of politics. So, we'll see what actually happens between now and then. And you respond accordingly and vote or act differently.

utterances.speaker: PERGRAM
utterances.utterance: Pelosi won't have President Trump as a foil this time. However, she does have president-elect Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: It is opportunity for us to work together with the president, especially when he's a unifier like Joe Biden.

utterances.speaker: PERGRAM (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Pelosi knows it probably just takes a call from the president-elect to shore up any wavering Democrats to support her bid for speaker, Bret.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Chad, thank you. This is the first day absentee ballots for Georgia's January 5th Senate runoffs are being mailed out to residents. This has new attention is being paid to some of the past statements of one of the Democrats on the ballot. Correspondent Jonathan Serrie has tonight's runoff recap from Atlanta.

utterances.speaker: JONATHAN SERRIE, FOX NEWS CHANNEL CORRESPONDENT (Voice over)
utterances.utterance: With partisan control of the Senate hinging on to Georgia runoffs, ad spending has already topped $120 million according to the marketing firm Ad Impact.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: The only way to beat this virus is to give our new president the chance to succeed.

utterances.speaker: SERRIE
utterances.utterance: Today, Democrats Jon Ossoff and Raphael Warnock accused Georgia's Republican senators of enabling President Trump's attacks on the integrity of Georgia's elections. While Senators Kelly Loeffler and David Perdue demanded Warnock apologize for comments in a 2011 sermon.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: He said that you can't serve in the military and serve God.

utterances.speaker: SERRIE
utterances.utterance: Warnock says he was preaching on the Bible verse no man can serve two masters, meaning you must first commit to God before earthly pursuits.

utterances.speaker: REV. RAPHAEL WARNOCK (D), SENATORIAL CANDIDATE OF GEORGIA
utterances.utterance: The folks and my congregation, many of whom are veterans weren't confused at all about the message that day, that when you commit yourself to something larger than yourself, you become better at that, whether that is serving in the military or serving in the U.S. Senate.

utterances.speaker: SERRIE
utterances.utterance: Today is the final day of Georgia's statewide audit of ballots in the November election, and the first day counties can mail out absentee ballots for the January 5th runoff. Their increased use concerns some Republicans.

utterances.speaker: SEN. LINDSEY GRAHAM (R-SC)
utterances.utterance: All I'm asking for is that, Georgia, have a bipartisan group to verify a signature on a mail ballot, not leave it up to a single individual.

utterances.speaker: SERRIE (on camera)
utterances.utterance: Georgia election officials rejected 2,011 absentee ballots in the November general election for missing or non-matching signatures. That's a 350 percent increase over the 2018 general election, simply because more absentee ballots were requested. The state's rejection rate of 0.15 percent remain the same for both elections. Bret?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Jonathan Serrie in Atlanta. Jonathan, thank you. Up next, the Facebook tool that keeps track of you, like it or not. We'll dig deeper into the controversy over Centra.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Stocks sold off late in the day. The Dow lost 345 today. The S&P 500 fell 42. The NASDAQ gave back 98. We're learning new details tonight about some of the ways big tech is keeping track of you and your family. There's growing controversy over a Facebook tool that makes it all possible without your knowledge. But the head of the company insists he's not familiar with it. Here is Edward Lawrence of Fox Business.

utterances.speaker: EDWARD LAWRENCE, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK CORRESPONDENT (voice over)
utterances.utterance: Facebook executive searching for answers in a sea of accusations about tracking and company behavior. Missouri Senator Josh Hawley shot Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, confronting him with whistleblower information that Facebook routinely tracks people across the Internet with a program called Centra, as well as works with other text giants on what and who to censor. Today, Facebook confirming to Fox Business, Centra exists, but adding, it's only used to aid complex investigations to inauthentic behavior. Zuckerberg dodged the questions yesterday.

utterances.speaker: SEN. JOSH HAWLEY (R-MO)
utterances.utterance: What is the Facebook internal tool called Centra?

utterances.speaker: MARK ZUCKERBERG, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, FACEBOOK
utterances.utterance: Senator, I'm not aware of any tool with that name.

utterances.speaker: HAWLEY
utterances.utterance: There's a demonstrative now over my shoulder, Centra is a tool that Facebook uses to track its users not just on Facebook, but across the entire Internet.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE
utterances.utterance: Senator Hawley also pressing Facebook about coordinated censorship. Hawley, says the whistleblower outlined for him the tool called tasks that allows communication between Facebook, Twitter, and Google about what topics, hashtags, and people to censor. Facebook says it's for investigations. Adding, "We are proud of the work we do together on security issues and fighting child exploitation -- and are public about that." Representative Steve Scalise, adding, social media companies are on a slippery slope.

utterances.speaker: REP. STEVE SCALISE (R-LA)
utterances.utterance: They're not just letting content out there, by the way. The idea that they should have those Section 30 -- 230 protections against being sued, it shouldn't apply if you're starting to pick and choose whose views you're going to put out there in the public square.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE (on camera)
utterances.utterance: A senators on both sides of the aisle now pledge to make changes to Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act, which would remove immunity from lawsuits the companies enjoy. And Senator Hawley said that would be the first step in reining in the power over speech and personal data companies like Facebook wield. Bret?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Edward, thanks. Up next, we talked to governors from both parties with differing ideas on how to keep their residents safe from coronavirus.

utterances.speaker: GOV. LAURA KELLY (D-KS)
utterances.utterance: The last component in our new all of the above strategy is an executive order that I'm issuing today, implementing a new statewide face-covering protocol.

utterances.speaker: GOV. TATE REEVES (R-MS)
utterances.utterance: We're not going to participate in a nationwide lockdown.

utterances.speaker: GOV. TONY EVERS (D-WI)
utterances.utterance: The best way to get through this is to -- is to be together by from afar.

utterances.speaker: GOV. MIKE DEWINE (R-OH)
utterances.utterance: I don't intend to send agents out to knock on people's doors, go into their backyard, go down to their rec room.

utterances.speaker: GOV. GAVIN NEWSOM (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: I made a bad mistake. I need to preach and practice. Not just preach and not practice.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Governors across the nation with different approaches to curbing the spread of the coronavirus, and it is spreading throughout the country. As we told you at the top of the program, surging cases forcing many state and local governments to take some major steps toward containment. The last 24-hour reporting period showed almost 162,000 new infections for a total of 11-1/3 million cases. We are going to talk tonight about regulations, restrictions, other possible ways to deal with the situation we are seeing in the country. Joining us, governors from both parties. Republican Tate Reeves of Mississippi will be with us shortly. First up, we'll talk to Kansas Democratic Governor Laura Kelly. Governor Kelly, thanks for being here. I know you're dealing with surges in your state as we're seeing across the country. What are you doing now to deal with that?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: Well, we are experiencing a huge surge just like many other states. But just today, in response to that, we introduced a sort of multi-pronged approach to this. I did issue another executive order mandating face- covering protocols. But we did it with a little bit of a twist. I had done that once before in July. This time around, we've set the protocols, we've set the standard for across Kansas. But we are giving those counties that previously opted out of the mandate and there were about 70 of 105 counties here in Kansas that did opt-out. We're going to give them a one week to put together their own ordinance, instead of opting into our ordinance. So that they can have a little control, have a little ownership, and make it flexible enough to allow them to do what they think will work in their county. Then, in addition to that --

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Governor, do you see a lot of pushback?

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: No. Actually, I'm not. You know, I had conversations with Republican leadership yesterday and today. I've had conversations with -- my offices had conversations with the Kansas Chamber of Commerce and other business entities. And I think we actually have a lot of support for taking this approach because we are giving some flexibility and autonomy to our local elected officials to put in place what worked for them. Do they need to have a face-covering protocol in place? Absolutely. But we think, and we've seen what we've learned over the last nine months is that one size does not fit all. And so, we want them to develop something that will work for them. But in addition to that, we're going to support them through a very robust public service announcement program that's being put together by our Kansas Hospital Association, the Kansas Chamber of Commerce, the Kansas Farm Bureau, and other groups. That will begin airing next week, just before Thanksgiving. That will encourage people, give them the education they need to understand the importance of the face coverings. So, we're going to do that. And then, we've formed a partnership with our Kansas leadership center, which trains local leaders all across the state on routine basis. They're going to engage about 2,000 of their alums. And we're going to create a virus busting task force that will work all across the state in our local communities, with folks, their neighbors, their friends, to encourage them to follow the face mask protocols, but also to do all of the other things that will mitigate the spread of this virus.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: And allow us to keep our business open, allow us to keep our schools open, and decrease the pressure on our hospitals.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Right. And what I'm not hearing from you is lockdown, because there are a lot of people across the country that are fearful of that. They saw what happened March to May, Kansas dropped, like the nation, some 37 percent as far as businesses and tax revenues coming into your state. You've had in Wichita, I guess, suicides up more than 70 percent, and we're seeing some of that from some of this lockdown fear. But I'm not hearing that in what you're saying as far as how you're going to address it, and you're also waiting, obviously, for a vaccine.

utterances.speaker: KELLY
utterances.utterance: Yes, we are not going that route. We have learned a lot over the nine months of this pandemic, and we took some pretty drastic action at the beginning because we didn't know anything else to do. But now we do know that there are other ways to mitigate the spread of this virus, and we've worked very closely with our business communities from way back at the beginning of this time, we've worked with our school districts, and we're working with just the general public and our healthcare professionals and all of those to put in place things that we know will mitigate the spread of the virus and buy us the time until a vaccine is developed and distributed widely.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Governor, we appreciate your time. Good luck fighting this thing. Every governor is dealing with it, from Topeka, Kansas. Thank you. Let's bring in Mississippi Republican Governor Tate Reeves. Governor Reeves, thanks for being here. You just heard Governor Kelly from Kansas. Your thoughts, what are you doing?

utterances.speaker: GOV. TATE REEVES, (R-MS)
utterances.utterance: Bret, thanks for having me on today. And one of the things that I was glad to hear my colleague say is that one size does not fit all. It's why those that are clamoring for a national strategy do not realize what those of us as governors that are in the trenches, that are working every single day. What's best for Kansas today is not necessarily what's best for Mississippi. And in fact, I have got 82 counties in my great state, and what's best in the northeast part of our state where numbers are in a certain spot versus what's best for the Mississippi gulf coast are different. And that's why we are taking a county by county approach. We began this dating all the way back to late June, early July. And we have an objective criteria in place in which if any county has more than 200 cases over a two-week period, or more than 500 cases per 100,000 residents, then we put additional measures in place, more strict measures in place, which may or may not include a mask mandate. It certainly includes having smaller-sized gatherings and other things such as that. And so, again, it's very important that governors have autonomy to do what's best for their constituents. And when you talk about the notion of lockdowns, one of the reasons people are so concerned about that right now is because some of the leading experts that are advising the Biden administration are certainly suggesting that. And so we're going to push back against that as well. I'm glad to hear that there are Republican and Democrat governors across the country that agree that that's not the right approach to take.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Governor, you're seeing your hospitalization rates go up. You have a test positive rate in Mississippi, according to Johns Hopkins, at 18.8 percent. That's a concerning number, but you're saying you are handling it different in different parts of the state.

utterances.speaker: REEVES
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, the reality is that we have seen a slight uptick in cases. We are nowhere near where we were back during the summer months. If you'll recall, many of the southeastern conference states, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, Florida, Georgia had a very, very challenging summer. At that time, we actually had 1,250 hospitalizations at our peak, and that was on July 26th. Today we have approximately 850. So we're somewhere in the neighborhood of 65 to 70 percent of total hospitalizations at our peak. We're very pleased that there are a number of good things that are coming out that are going to help us deal with this virus. The antibody opportunities that exist in terms of the therapeutics is a huge move in the right direction for us. I was talking with a state health officers about that earlier today. It's going to allow us to treat as many as 700 patients in the near term. In addition to that, the vaccine is just around the corner. And so what we all need to be talking about is how do we bridge the gap from where we find ourselves today where we are seeing rises cases in our state and every other state around the nation, how do we bridge that gap from today to when we have more and more distribution of the two vaccines that have literally in the last couple weeks been discussed?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: You mentioned SEC football. That's a big deal down there. You had the Texas A&M-Ole Miss game canceled. Do you think SEC is going to be able to finish this season?

utterances.speaker: REEVES
utterances.utterance: We'll, there's not doubt that we've had some challenges over the last several weeks. There's been a large number of games that have been canceled. And the reason for that is because we're seeing significant numbers increase in community transmission. As total numbers increase across our states, then obviously a larger number of those associated with the program, football players, et cetera, are testing positive as well, which is making challenges. So my plea to everyone in the southeastern conference and everyone who cares about college football around the country or cares about sports in general is the best way we can ensure that they go forward is by doing our part. Let's do the little things that make a difference. Let's wear a mask. Let's stay in small groups even over Thanksgiving. Let's be personally responsible. We don't need the government to tell us what to do. We as individuals just need to recognize that we can do some little things to make a big difference.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Across party lines, Governor Reeves, we appreciate your time. Governor Kelly earlier from Kansas. Thank you both for being on, dealing with this coronavirus pandemic. Up next, the State Department says China wants to replace the U.S. as the most powerful nation on earth. We will look at how they might try to do that and what the U.S. is doing about it.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: We are getting fresh information about just how seriously the U.S. government is taking the growing threat from China. A new report says the Beijing leadership is intent on displacing the U.S. as the world's most powerful nation. Correspondent Benjamin Hall looks at the implications of that tonight from London.

utterances.speaker: BENJAMIN HALL, FOX NEWS CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: A new generation of Chinese fighter pilots landing on a new generation of Chinese carriers, wargames simulating the naval invasion of Taiwan, further arrests of opposition lawmakers in Hong Kong, and high in the Himalayas, reports that China used a secret microwave weapon to incapacitate Indian soldiers. China has also now signed a major trade deal with 14 other Asian-Pacific countries, the first that unites China, Japan, South Korea, and Australia. China has been flexing its military and economic muscles, and the State Department is paying close attention, issuing a warning to the incoming administration, saying "The CCP aims not merely at preeminence within the established world order, but to fundamentally revise world order, placing the People's Republic of China at the center and serving Beijing's authoritarian goals and hegemonic ambitions." President Trump has repeatedly criticized Democrats for failing to address China's behavior, and there remains little clarity on President-elect Biden's plans for the U.S./China relationship.

utterances.speaker: JOE BIDEN, (D) PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.utterance: We need to be aligned with the other democracies, another 25 percent or more, so that we can set the rules of the road instead of having China and others dictate outcomes because they are the only game in town.

utterances.speaker: HALL
utterances.utterance: China has congratulated President-elect Biden, but they remain cautious of President Trump. State media reporting that Beijing is preparing for what they say could be a, quote, final act of madness from President Trump to sabotage Biden's presidency.

utterances.speaker: HALL
utterances.utterance: There is a growing and bipartisan belief that the U.S. needs a more aggressive approach towards China. Whether President-elect Biden shares that approach remains to be seen. Bret?

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Benjamin, thank you. Up next, the panel on the vote recount, the Georgia runoffs, the latest with the coronavirus, all of that. First beyond our borders tonight. German police unleash watercannons and pepper spray in an effort to scatter thousands of protestors angry about a new legal framework for enforcing coronavirus restrictions. The legislation was passed by parliament today in Germany today. Police detained 190 people, nine officers were injured. The head of the U.N. atomic watchdog agency confirms reports Iran has begun operating centrifuges installed at an underground site. But the director general of the International Atomic Energy Agency says the centrifuges were moved from another facility, so the country's overall uranium enriching capabilities have not increased. Today the U.S. imposed broad sanctions targeting Iran and blacklisted a foundation controlled by the country's Supreme Leader. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo visited Israel today along with Bahrain's foreign minister, which was a first official visit from the kingdom to Israel. For his part Pompeo's visit may include a tour of a West Bank winery, which would be the first time a top American diplomat has visited an Israeli settlement. Just some of the other stories beyond our borders tonight. We'll be right back.

utterances.speaker: MARK GODSEY, MICHIGAN BOWLING ALLEY OWNER
utterances.utterance: In my whole life I never thought my government would tell me I have to close. I can go through recessions and I can do all that. It's my fault if I don't make it. It's not my fault this time, and I have no choice. And I'm only a mile from the Indiana border, and they're open. And so it makes it pretty hard to swallow.

utterances.speaker: GOV. GRETCHEN WHITMER, (D-MI)
utterances.utterance: I have incredible empathy for what they're struggling with, and yet we have to follow the epidemiology, the public health experts, and make decisions that combat the spread before our hospitals get overwhelmed and before we hit 1,000 deaths a week in Michigan, because that's what the modeling is telling us where we're headed right now.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Small business owners really trying to figure out how to keep going in this environment as different state and local governments decide to do different things with the coronavirus. This as we have just passed, according to Johns Hopkins University, 250,000 deaths in the U.S., the cases now 11,485,000. That is eighth in the world per capita when it comes to deaths of the major countries in the world. That's where we are at this moment a week before Thanksgiving. Let's bring in our panel, Charles Hurt, opinion editor for "The Washington Times," A.B. Stoddard, associate editor at Real Clear Politics, and Byron York, chief political correspondent for the "Washington Examiner." Charlie, you heard Governors Kelly and Reeves from Kansas and Mississippi trying to thread the needle here to not hurt small businesses, but also deal with this surge. And it's a real challenge. CHARLES HURT, OPINION EDITOR, "WASHINGTON TIMES": It sure is a real challenge, and I think that in a lot of ways we may be understating just how much this crisis will define politics probably for the next 15 years in this country. And I think that -- quite frankly I think it stands to hurt politicians who are trying to do these lockdowns and do these mandates, because I think that a lot of people feel like we've tried those things and, obviously, the pandemic continues. It continues to spread. And at the end of the day, it's going to be things like the therapeutics, the vaccines, and of course personal responsibility across the board that is going to be what -- Americans are funny. They can have a lot of funny opinions about a lot of different things. But one thing that they really do care about, they like their freedom. And I think that these kinds of mandates, especially when the people that are pushing them are violating their own mandates, I think that sort of thing tends to turn a political environment toxic.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: A.B., the poster boy for that, it appears, this week is the California Governor Gavin Newsom, who was shot, photographed at this dinner at the French Laundry in Napa with a group of people, without a mask, in an area closed down just after giving this big speech about how Thanksgiving had to be locked down and people need to be wearing masks at all times, even with family members, under 10 people. Here is his apology. Take a listen.

utterances.speaker: GOV. GAVIN NEWSOM, (D-CA)
utterances.utterance: As soon as I sat down at the larger table, I realized it was a little larger group than I had anticipated. And I made a bad mistake. You can quibble about the guidelines, et cetera, et cetera, but the spirit of what I'm preaching all the time was contradicted, and I got to own that. And so I want to apologize to you, because I need to preach and practice, not just preach and not practice.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: So that's happening to politicians all over the country, too. But the bottom line is everybody has to figure out a way to deal with this.

utterances.speaker: A.B. STODDARD, ASSOCIATE EDITOR, REAL CLEAR POLITICS
utterances.utterance: Yes, I wonder what the nurses and doctors who have been through this all year in California and have had just been in a state of complete anguish and trauma, if they're still alive and uninfected, think of the governor doing that and then trying to backtrack in that kind of a speech. The problem is there was never going to be a safe scenario in an indoor party at the French Laundry, and even if it wasn't on video, certainly his fancy friends were going to brag that they were at dinner with him at the French Laundry. So the thing is ludicrous. Everyone has to lead by example, and they have to take responsibility for the fact that our healthcare system is at the breaking point. And we know from the models and the experts, because they have studied what has happened Memorial Day, July Fourth, Sturgis rally, on and on, what happens when a Trump rally comes to a county -- all these things create more infection. And we know what will happen to our hospitals at Christmastime if everyone plans to gather, at Thanksgiving. And what the governor of California did is completely hypocritical, and he is not living up to the sacrifice he is asking people to make so that we can have space in the ICU wards of these hospitals for people who are not taking responsibility and are spreading the disease.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Byron, obviously Operation Warp Speed has been very successful to get us as a country to this point with not only the vaccines and the logistics that is yet to come, but also the therapeutics that are coming today, fast test at home approved by Pfizer. Those are all positive things, but they don't come right away. BRYON YORK, CHIEF POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT, "WASHINGTON EXAMINER": No, it's going to take a while. And there will be a big political fight over the distribution of those that will straddle the end of the Trump administration and the beginning of the Biden administration. I think the real main fact to remember about vaccines is that President Trump promised a vaccine in record time, and there will be vaccines, plural, in record time. But I thought it was really interesting what Governor Kelly and Governor Reeves were telling you. Clearly, they don't believe in any sort of national one size fits all policy. They don't believe even in statewide one size fits all policies. They are making policies county by county in their states, depending on conditions, and there was absolutely zero taste among either one, Republican and Democrat, for lockdowns. They felt like they learned a lot during the lockdown period months ago, and they don't want to do that again even when the virus is a big threat.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Charlie, do you think families, a lot of them are saying if you are number 11, you're out on the porch, 10 or under on the inside? What do you think families around the country are dealing with when it comes to these restrictions?

utterances.speaker: HURT
utterances.utterance: I really don't think that's the case. I think people are going to continue to operate in a responsible way. They are going to wear masks if they can't social distance. They're going to wash their hands. They're going to keep their distance. But I don't think that people are going to be cutting off people from Thanksgiving. I know my family certainly won't be cutting off people from the Thanksgiving table because of this.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: If I have a TV outside, I'm OK. I can sit on the porch. Panel, thank you so much. When we come back, reunited, and you know the rest.

utterances.speaker: BAIER
utterances.utterance: Finally tonight, back together again. Old work pals, Marion Darbyshire and Winnie Shaw were inseparable friends as young apprentices at a British sewing factory. The pair eventually lost contact with Winnie left that factory. And after 73 years the two were reunited after bumping into each other at the Manchester, England, care home where they both live. How about that? Elsewhere in England, Harry Wilsden and his wife Doreen were reunited in a care home in Darlington after nearly two months apart. The pair were separated after Harry contracted the coronavirus. Doreen said she could hardly believe her eyes when she saw her husband and that's a good thing. Thanks for inviting us into your home tonight. That's it for the SPECIAL REPORT. Fair, balanced and unafraid. "THE STORY" hosted by Martha MacCallum starts right now.
